WRITING.TEXT: Muchas veces eso se debe a la ignorancia de la persona a cargo. Hace unos aos estaba dando clases de ingls a gente del depto. IT de una empresa importante en su sector y nos pusimos a hablar del tema Linux, OpenOffice y dems yerbas. Ellos me contaron que haban probado con OpenOffice y que como prueba piloto lo haban metido en un par de sucursales de la empresa, todo con resultados muy positivos. Cuando estaba por vencer la licencia con MS, fueron al director general de la empresa a presentarle la idea de migrar a OpenOffice haciendo hincapi en la guita que se ahorrara. Le instalaron OpenOffice al tipo y le mostraron que todo funcionaba a la perfeccin. La respuesta del Director General, un tipo de 50 pico, fue que no le convenca porque "era muy distinto" y se iba a tener que acostubrar a usarlo.

We all got "fired", got paid severance package and whatever vacation we had not taken, and then rehired under the new owners (which included a pay cut, but that's another story). I think it's perfectly fine to criticise the conduct of the referendum (perhaps with a little aftertaste of sour grapes) because the reduction of a complicated issue to a single choice resulted in the decision meaning many different things to different people. Some people want to leave the EU, but remain in the EEA, some leavers want to control immigration completely, some accept that the EEA is a compromise.
It is the problem with referendums in general. A complex issue being reduced to a Yes or No question. And to make it worse, there are a lot of of people who will use a referendum as a protest vote, they will vote against whatever it is that the government (or another political entity) supports, without paying too much attention to the question at hand, encouraged, of course, by politicians hoping to profit from that.

That would depend a lot on how the pesticides are applied. A couple of years ago, I was in a press trip organised by a Czech brewery. They took us to one of the cooperatives that supply them with barley for their maltings. They told us they have to be very careful with how they spray their fields, which are right next to a village, and the pretty strict guidelines they must follow.
We live in a village outside Prague and there is a field right behind the fence of our backyard. We've been living for eight years, we grow lots of stuff. Never had a problem and the weeds that grow in the 2m-wide path between the field and our fence are thriving. The way they spray the fields, though, as close to the ground as possible, and only early on in the season. After that, we don't see any machinery until harvest. They do rotate crops, every year there's something different. This year is rapeseed, last year was barley and sugar beets...
Business as usual in Eastern Europe, it seems.

Meanwhile, corn varieties with higher levels of vitamin A developed using non-GMO breeding methods are being grown in Africa and helping to address vitamin A deficiency there.
That'd be great, and I wish that project success, but could it be introduced in the Philippines or other regions that heavily depend on rice successfully and without significant environmental disruption? Can that corn be successfully introduced *everywhere* it'd be needed in Africa, successfully and without significant environmental disruption? Those are the questions Greenpeace hardly addresses.

It will greatly depend on what sort of place you'll go and how you behave. If you go to a beer garden or another place where you 18 yo mate can get the drinks AND you don't make too much noise, nobody will care.
However, if the police happens to come to check IDs (which is not rare, specially at this time of the year), you might get in trouble. But fine, I guess you know the risk. The thing is, though, that it will not be only your problem, but pub's, too, who will be issued a hefty fine, at the very least. I have friends who run pubs, and they fucking hate that, really. If a pub owner figures out you are minors, they will kick you out in a not very polite manner.
My advice is: Do Not Do It. Do you want to get pissed? Fine. Have your mate buy a few bottles at a supermarket, and do it in your room, but do not get anyone else in trouble.

WRITING.TEXT:
Story time:
Back in 1996 (I can't believe it's been 20 years already), I went on a holiday to New Zealand. My boss bad given me some money to bring him something traditional and I found a beautifully carved Patu -- [you can see it here](http://www.kiwitreasure.com/887-patu-maori-war-club-carving.htm). I didn't have space in my luggage and I put it in my carry-on.
The security guard at the gate was a big-ass Maori bloke (just like pretty much every Maori, regardless of gender), who spotted the thing when my bag went through the x-ray. He opened it and pulled the big bugger out and asked if I knew what it was.
"Yeah," I said, "it's a patu. I've bought it because I'll be asking my boss for a raise on Monday, and if he refuses, I'll use it on his head".
Big-ass Maori dude security guard LOLed and asked his colleague if I could get on the plane with that weapon. "Yeah!" The colleague said, waving his hand nonchalantly.
What a time to be alive! Now, you can't even bring a fucking bottle of mineral water!

Not loud enough for other people to hear me, but just so I have to go read every single word, and pay close attention to punctuation and stress. I've found that I'm more focused on the text. Right now I'm reading Lawrence Norfolk's "In the Shape of a Boar", the first part of which is quite demanding, and I'm enjoying it a lot more whenever I can read it out loud.

WRITING.TEXT: It's almost a treatise on pre-internet conspiratardism. The story is basically about three scholars working for a publisher who, just for shit and giglges, decide to create the ultimate conspiracy theory, a kind of world domination plan that includes the usual suspects: the Templars, the Illuminaty, the Rosicrucians, the Jews, different royal houses, the Church, the Jesuits, the Nazis, Hollow Earth, Alchemy.... the only ones missing are the Bilderberg Group and Aliens. All with arbitrary connections that are, however, logical. Its all fun and games until they start taking it seriously.
